comments.commentBody:
I'm mystified by the folks who say "good riddance" and claim that Dennis Ross was a "shill" for Israel and perhaps even a Mossad agent. The attack is so loony that it should not be dignified by a response -- except that so many different people seem to have bought into it.

Ross has been one of the sanest thinkers on Middle East policy for many years. His departure is a sad day for the U.S. (not just the Obama Administration). We have lost yet another one of the "good guys" (though I certainly understand and respect his promise to his wife).

We often lament that "the media" tears down our public figures, but the responses to this article show that we ourselves are to blame. A man devotes decades of his life to one of the most intractable problems in the world, and how do we react? With spite and conspiracy theories! Is that who we really are? I certainly hope not.

Thank you, Mr. Ross. Your served our country well.

As Robert Kaplan has noted, water is the most important fluid of the 21st century. Maybe, if we can delay long enough (I'm an optimist!), Americans will come around to understanding this fact. We cannot afford to gamble with the Ogallala.

And then, there is global warming. But, if global warming is completely discounted, there is still the possibility of destroying the Ogallala.

As I read the comments concerning the pipeline and the reelection of Obama it boggles the mind knowing there are so many uninformed people living in the same place, it's quite scary. Obama is wasting both the pipeline company's money as well as our money both taxes and in consumer prices. For people to worry about environmental damage or damage to water aquifers is nearly comical. If we look at the Alaskan Pipeline and the lack of problems, there's no reason to think this pipeline will be any different, in fact it should be better due to advanced products and techniques.

You ask, does Penn State "have it in them" to cancel the remaining season?  Why not ask whether Pennsylvania has it in it to cancel Penn State's academic year?  It was the reputation of Penn State that was being protected, not of playing football.  The people who are guilty should not be confused with the football players or fans.  Are you naive enough to think that human nature changes when you take a  clumsy swat at it?
You have not seen anything yet.   Prison for all the enablers!!!

The behavior of the Penn State students yesterday testifies to the reality that this crime was allowed to continue because an idea of football (and perhaps its economics) trumped the law, ethics, and even human decency. Penn is an educational institution. Apparently it has been teaching the wrong things. Football, and its importance on campus, is the cloud that has allowed appalling and criminal misjudgment among coaches and administrators. Its disproportionate role at Penn seems to have taught students that child rape doesn't matter when a beloved coach is on the line. It is the student behavior that signifies how far football has driven Penn from its educational and human mission—and THAT should cost the university its football season. We may be sorry for the students who will not get to play, but the lesson all Penn students will learn will be much more valuable to them than winning any game.
Kick the dirtball footballers out of the university for good. They are the lowest of the low.

Sure. Don't penalize the players just because they vandalize our cities, rape and murder people, engage in domestic violence, litter our streets, stage dogfighting tournaments and pervert our institutions of higher learning. Just let them ride roughshod over our communities. Don't worry---we'll pick up the pieces for these scoundrels. We always do.

Like it or not college football is big business, should all the restaurant, bar, hotel and shop owners be punished for one dispicable human being, one coward and the inaction of a few more?  Punish the Universities of Nebraska, Ohio st and Wisconsin.  Lets punish the good people in Columbus, Camp Randle, the airlines.  College football is certainly a monster but hundreds of thousands of people benefit and depend on this monster for their livelyhood.

Penn State did the absolutely right thing by sacking Paterno & Spanier but that can only be the start. Now we learn that allegations against Sandusky have been hushed up for 10 years plus; HOW could corruption get any worse? We ought to be able to see--with blinding clarity--that the Penn State football program is rotten to the core and nothing short of reconstruction AFTER at least a year's worth of self-imposed contrition is the only way this program can be allowed to restart.

I recall the tempest ex-UNI professor (and "Bridges of Madison County" author) Robert James Waller ignited here in IA back in the '80's when he proposed that in order to satisfy the apparent NEED people seem to have for sports teams to assert their local pride, identities, or whatever, that need should be satisfied by leasing the uniforms and facilities to professional teams and abandon the pretense that these guys study Plato six days, then suit up on Saturday. Scandal and outrage would still be possible but it wouldn't permanently blight an otherwise valuable public institution. Like it or not, many will now speak of "Pedophile State" for the rest of our lives.

In the aftermath I'm hoping at the very least that PSU and every other college/university will recognize that allowing one coach or team to become the public face of your institution, and the embodiment of its prestige (as PSU did with Paterno) is idolatrous and obviously DANGEROUS. Tear that statue DOWN!
Seems as if you can't wait to shove this dirt under the rug as quickly as you can.
Ah, it's so nice to hear the voice of reason from a writer with the proper perspective on this scandal.

It's because this is bigger than football that Penn State must step up and show that it understands that by cancelling the season. The whole disgusting mess exists because the institution put football above all else.

Institutional control....

the NCAA mantra... Let's see how they handle it.
They say it depends on legal process. That has never mattered in the past. SMU paid players and their program has never recovered from the death penalty. There were no legal charges. Wouldn't a decade long program of PSU tacit support of child sodomy be a just a bit worse than paying players?

We all know the outcome. PSU is big time (ESPN, CBS, etc.) and that i$ what the NCAA cares about.

I agree with Salzberg in regard to eliminating football in colleges. But that’s not enough - eliminate football from public school athletic programs, which are the feeders to the college programs. Coaches of football (other sports too) want to win at all costs and exploit the players along the way by ruining their bodies and brains (concussions, etc.) in order to bolster their winning tally. Disgraceful. High school students often travel long distances to play a game and return home quite late, too late for homework and adequate time to sleep.

The economy is strained, too strained to uphold this sports mania in schools and colleges. Budgets are being cut in ways that harm the quality of education, but sports is somehow off limits from cuts, mostly. School administrators devote an enormous amount of time to sports. No end to it all.

It seems quite obvious to me that it was not just Joe Paterno that knew or suspected that Sandusky was attacking children. They need to end the football season, fire everyone, the NCAA should allow the players to transfer with an extra year of eligibility. Once the criminal and civil cases are settled then the University community can decide if they want to re-start football on that campus.
How can you care more about the game of football than those children who were raped in the football team locker room and showers? If you care more about football than the horrific crimes so many children were subjected to then you need to re-think your morals and priorities.

The molesting of way too many youngsters that was let to continue way beyond the time it should have is horrible.  Joe Paterno did tell his superiors about the horrible experience of a sweet, young boy way back in the late 1900s, but unfortunately, it appears he did not follow through when the superiors did not take the case to the police.  That is an ethical, moral thing against Joe Paterno.  It appears media has tried & found guilty Joe Paterno.  It appears Paterno's superiors have tried him, and found him guilty. The now assistant coach reported what he saw, but he too, did nothing to follow through when nothing seemed to be happening; he did not report it to the police.  As far as we know, the present football players had no knowledge of any molesting, so why should they be punished for something they did not do?  My opinion is that Penn State should continue playing the rest of the season.
I'm speechless. We are living a modern day Sodom and Gomorrah. Don't the Penn state family have any shame?

Canceling the season in light of the horrific happenings at Penn State is the right thing to do. It shows the victims, boys, children, who were raped and abused, that what happened to them is indeed wrong and the entire institution is attempting to make amends. It shows the nation that child abuse will not be tolerated. It shows the players that they are part of something bigger than football, they are part of the entire university that is supposed to teach, uphold and advance the values of society. If I was a player on that team I'd be proud to stand up and say "I will not play" to honor the victims of this tragedy. It shows that a human life is worth so much more than a game.

Using the misdeeds of members of the administration and coaches as an excuse to satisfy a dislike of college football is in itself shameful. They should not cancel the season and punish a large number of people to satisfy the preferences of a handful.

This argument merely emphasises how much obsession with sports can erode ethics. Who cares about Penn State's record, a chance at a league title or Senior Day? That is precisely the football-über-Alles mindset that led to the cover-up in this scandal.

A few disappointed seniors is hardly worth the grotesque spectacle of playing football as usual.

"...molding men for the future."

Like former players Jerry Sandusky and Mike McQueary? Or did you mean the 27 Penn State players found guilty of criminal charges between 2002 and 2008?

When I read about the police officer who was maced by a student in a gas mask last night, that was the last straw for me! We can't send police, who have no reason to be there except to protect others, into that situation again. Far as I'm concerned, they should shut the place down and have parents come and get their kids.

Would you feel safe at Saturday's game? Shut it down. This school needs to hit a big Restart button.

Why don't they simply shut down the entire university for the rest of the year?   This was a problem that went beyond football, and shutting down would send a message to the students that PSU is not nearly as important as they seem to think it is.
